author: 0xsadcat
content: <@!301186049323958275> is there any hope for your eip 2803 in berlin? that would be an absolutely fantastic upgrade if only because of the approve/do something pattern. there's also an enormous security benefit, as that would stop the insecure practice of forbidding contract calls for security.

author: 0xsadcat
content: also I think the "Any CALL operations that send value take their value from the EOA that signed the transaction." part is a mistake - it's more secure to only allow to send the sent value.

author: zerowei4320
content:
2803 is interesting i can see large scale abuse vectors here as it would be hard for users to audit the actual byte code itself, nick johnson had a proposal to allow hoisting of code into an eoas code slot. 

Conversely 2803 might be analogous to that endeavor.

author: 0xsadcat
content: for standard operations a delegatecall (in the eoa context) to a known code would fix this risk, with arbitrary bytecode intended as an option for advanced users. metamask/etc should be able to decode the simple delegatecall pattern and display a scary warning for arbitrary bytecode.

author: zerowei4320
content: Agreed but reliance on an interface to save you is not a good standard. Ethereum execution principles ensure eoas are sacred land. It’s why contracts can’t modify the eoa state.

author: zerowei4320
content: Intentional deployment into my eoa slot ensures there is an initiation step.
